text:
DONNA NOVITSKY:
Hello, everybody. We're super excited
to be here, and share

our years of experience
in product management and companies.

So by way of introduction
just real quick, my name is Donna Novitsky.

I'm currently the CEO of a
startup company called, Yiftee, Y-I-F-T-E-E.

However, I started my
career as a product manager at Sunday Microsystems,
which I think

is the best job in the world. So congratulations on
making good choices. Went from there to
running a startup

company that went public, that
was living the Silicon Valley dream. Then became a venture
capitalist with a firm called

Mohr Davidow Ventures
on Sand Hill Road. And after that, went
back to my startup roots.

So basically, everything
I learned about startups, and bringing new
products to market, I learned in my first six
years as a product manager.

And that's what I'm
here to share today. Laura. LAURA MARINO: Hey,
great to be here.

I'm Laura Marino. I am currently the
Chief Product Officer at TruML, that's
a Fintech company.

But I've spent over 20
years leading product teams in large and small
organizations.

I have been across
industries primarily in B2B. But again, from large companies
like SAP, and Microsoft,

to smaller companies. And I would say
that the area where I am most passionate about
is what I call scaleup.

These are companies that are
going through the high-growth stage. So board member of a nonprofit
promoting women in diversity.

And I've been instructor at
Stanford for many years now.

DONNA NOVITSKY: Great. So what we're
going to talk about is the transitions
from starting with very

early on breathing life into
your very first products. If any of you are out
there in startups,

or thinking about startups,
this will be super useful. And then moving from there how
to accelerate time to volume

by avoiding all those
things that you learn working for big
companies that really

don't apply to young companies. Not just startups, but any
bringing any new products

to market. And then Laura is going to
talk about the five transitions that startups have to go
through in order to scale.

And those product
challenges, and then some broader strategies for
growth and expansive expansion.

So there should be
something for everyone here. And without further
ado, here we go. So number 1.

Mistakes to avoid
while breathing life into your first products. So I call this the tango.

It takes two to tango. What's going on here is
she's saying, follow my lead,

I'm building the product. And he's saying
follow my lead, I'm finding the
customers and market.

And the reality is you
have to be doing both. My experience in
venture capital, I saw so many entrepreneurs
that were thinking all they had

to do was build the product. And they were 100% focused
on building that product. Well, the field of dream
strategy, if we build it,

they will come. Does not work. So we're going to
talk about how do you build the market
at the same time

as you're building
your first products. But it's really hard.

You do not what you have
is your rockstar team, your exciting product
plans, your vision.

But you don't have a product,
you don't have customers, you don't have a reputation. Nobody knows who you are.

So how do you get those
very first customers? How do you get it off your
startup, your young company

off the ground? You have to use what you have
to get what you don't have.

But first, there is
a mindset that you need to have in order
to be successful.

Not only at this stage,
but at every stage. So my question for you is,
what do customers care about?

So they care about prices,
they care about functionality,

they care about quality. These are the answers
I usually get. But really, it's
bigger than that.

Customers care about themselves. So what you need to
do is put yourself

in your customers'
shoes at all times, whether you're tiny, whether
you're a large company.

You need to demonstrate that
you comprehend the customer's problem, you are competent
to solve or realize

nobody knows anything
about your product. There is no product. There is no market. There is no reputation.

So you have to convince
them that you understand where they're coming from.

So how do we do that? We're going to talk about that. But I'm going to
use this diagram to illustrate some of the
points that we'll be making.

So I'm sure many of you come
from the product development side of the house.

And you're pretty familiar with
the typical product development process.

Although this is vastly
simplified, I know. So your ideas start
out on a whiteboard,

you build something,
you debug it, you get it ready for
production, product goes live,

and eventually, you
roll it out, right? No big news there. But what you need to be
doing on the marketing side

is having these
exploratory meetings. So when you're conceptualizing
your product idea

getting your product, you need
to be talking to customers and finding out what
are their issues, what

are their opportunities, and
how does your idea, your concept stack up against what's
going on in their real world.

The next stage is going
through debugging and beta. So everybody understands
when I send my product out

for beta testing, I need to
get feedback on the product. That's not enough.

You need to also be
building credibility with those customers. Because if they don't trust
you, if you are not credible,

they're not going
to buy your product. And then you go to
having paying customers. You're not going to get
those paying customers

for your first products if you
haven't built that credibility, and that belief that you
understand their issues.

From there, you need to make
sure that those initial paying customers are referencing,
because that's

how you're going to grow. You're going to build on
those initial customers to get more like them. And then you have a market.

So we're going to use-- this
is all pretty obvious, right? I'm sure if I asked you
guys these questions,

you would say, yeah, this is, of
course, what we're going to do. So like what is she telling me? What's new here?

So rather than talk
about that anymore, I'm going to talk about all
the mistakes that people made.

And we're going to focus
on these first two. There's lots of
others we could spend an entire class, an
entire course covering

the mistakes that
product managers make in bringing products to market. But we're not going to do that. We're just going to talk
about these first two.

We need to make sure that you're
building your market early on, and you need to also think
about how you do that,

and what is your early
customer testing process. So where people go wrong?

Where entrepreneurs go wrong? Where product managers go wrong? Is they go, great. I had this idea,
the VCs love me,

my executive
management loved me, they gave us funding
to build this product. I'm going to go off, and I'm
going to build that product.
I'm going to build that vision. We're going to make it real. What's wrong with this?

If you have that
mindset, and you're not thinking about
the market, you're going to either build
too much, you're

going to build the
wrong stuff, or you're going to deliver too late. So this is where this concept
of a minimum viable product

comes in, which
I'm sure you're all familiar with because
everyone has read about MVPs and thinks about MVPs now.

But again, that's
not sufficient. What you have to also
be doing early on

is figuring out how do our
customers make purchase decisions, where does my
product fit in their hierarchy

of needs, and who are going to
be my early partners to build

to get paying customers,
to get references, and to build my market. Am I going to end up
in the right market

if I have these customers? So those are the things
you need to get right.

Building the product
vision is the danger zone. So again, if you do
this wrong, if you just

go out and build the product
without a lot of customer input, your engineering
department says OK, great.

Here's the product, go
get me some customers. This was fairly common in the
early days at Sun Microsystems

when I work there. And Sun can get away with
it, or could get away with it at the time because
they already had customers.

They had a reputation. They had a market. People would buy
the new product. If you're a young company, a
startup, this is what happens.

You go back to those
exploratory meetings, you go back to getting that
customer feedback incorporated

in your product, and
it can cost you 6 to 18 more months of development time.

And that could be
around of funding. So it could mean, well, the
bigger companies can get away

with it, brand new
startups cannot, you may not have that
funding to redo that product.

So what do you do to
address this problem? How do you get these early
on meetings with customers

or potential customers? I would say if you're
doing a B2B product, you need to meet with at
least 30 prospective customers

over a period of
three months while in parallel with the
product being developed.

And if you're doing a consumer
product, it's more than that. So you're thinking about during
this process, not just what

are the features and
functions that it needs to be, but what's going on with
my potential customers,

where does my product
rank, and their priorities. What are the greatest
pains that they have,

or how does this opportunity
fit for this business if it's a B2B company?

Who makes budgeting decisions? We had one of the
startups that I worked in when I was a VC,
had a great product for email

administrators. And so we tested it,
and built relationships with lots of email
administrators.

They loved it. And so we brought this
product to market. And the email administrators
couldn't get the budget

to buy the product. That is because when
you talk to the CFO, email administration was
not on the high priority

list of things to
fund in the company. So if you're not asking for
money for your early testers,

you're not going to
have all the information that you need to be successful. Does that make sense?

So the whole decision-making
and prioritization process of what's going on with
your customers is important.

Not just the features and
functions of your product. So how do you do that?

Because you don't even have
a product to show them yet. How do you get these meetings? What is it that you do in
order to learn what you

need to learn about the market? So remember I said you
need to use what you have to get what you don't have.

What you have is
a rock star team. Someone on your team is
what I call the player.

It's this guy. It's the person that can
make that unbelievable shot. So probably a number
of you are players,

and could play this
role in your company. But it's basically
someone that can be marketed in lieu of a product.

For example, I worked in
a supply chain company when I was a VC, the
CEO of that company

had many years of
experience with Deloitte, and was billed out
at $600 an hour

was a true supply chain expert. So people really
wanted to talk to him, customers, potential customers
really wanted to talk to him,

tell him their problems, get
his advice on how to fix them. And so we went out, we
met with our 30 customers.

Over three months, we got
a lot of great feedback. You have to watch
out with players. Sometimes they like to talk.

And your goal here is to listen. So these are the
characteristics of a player.

But the big thing is you are
listening, you are not talking. You are gathering information,
you are not selling.

You're building relationships
and credibility, that's what's important. Because the players
expertise has

more value to your
first customers and less risk than your product. So this player is basically
got to convince the customers

that he or she
comprehends the problem, is competent to address it, and
cares about these customers.

And they are betting on
that person, not the product when they make those
purchase decisions.

Think about that. So number 2. How to accelerate time to volume
by avoiding the big company

beta test process? I'm sure that a
number of you, like I brought 17 new
products to market at Sun

over a period of three years. So I was constantly going
through beta testing process.

I was constantly doing
product launches. I was constantly cranking
out new products.

And we had a process. And the process looks
something like this. We identified who will
test this product, who

will do us this quote favor
of testing the product. They would go out.

They would identify
features, quality issues, we would get that feedback, we
would refer it prioritize it,

we would refer it
to engineering, engineering would
make the changes. And then in parallel
the company was

learning how to deliver, how
to support the product, just everything that you
needed to be to bring a successful product to market.

But at that time, we weren't
really thinking about is this customer,
this tester going
to buy the product or not. They may buy it. They may not buy it. They gave us the feedback. That's what we wanted.

So then we finalize the product,
and we launch the product. So if you're doing
things this way, I want to tell you
or get everything
about how you do this. It is wrong for startups. Why is that?

Because this is
another where mistake, where entrepreneurs go wrong.

When they bring new
companies to market, they've been very successful
at other companies, previous

to their startup. They're on big
company autopilot. They know how to
launch products. Maybe they launch 17
products like I did.

They know the process. What's wrong with
this process is that they are doing insufficient
strategic customer and market

qualification upfront,
and they're not focused on those early beta
testers becoming referenceable.

What you have to get
is you have to be very strategic
about choosing who are going to be my early
testers because 80% of them

have to actually pay
money for this product. Remember all those things we
need to learn from the player.

You need to understand how
purchasing decisions are made, where the money comes from. So if you don't ask
for money, you're
not going to learn all that. And it's crucial. So why is this important?

Why is it different
in a startup? Because the big company
already has products,

they have a market,
they have reputation, they have existing
customers startups. Again, I'm talking
about breathing life

into first products. They do not. They don't have
any of that stuff. It completely changes the game.

So your early product
testing process is the first time
that your vision is being tested before the
true judge, the customers.

The customers have
to love your product, they have to buy
your product, it has to lead to
additional sales, and it

has to have those additional
sales in the right markets, so that word of mouth leads you
to a large market opportunity.

Or else, you go back to ground
zero in market development, and/or your market is too small.

So here's my tango slide. And for an example, you go
through your whole process,

and you end up with a market
that's just not interesting. So I've personally experienced.

I've personally
fallen for this trap. It's easy to fall into.

So what you have to do
is make sure you're not choosing wrong customers. A lot of people think, is
there a wrong customer?

What would a wrong customer be? A wrong customer is a
customer in the wrong market, their priorities
are not mainstream,

and the customer has
no intention of buying. So a customer in the bottom
line is a wrong customer

is a customer who is
not reprehensible. Your early product
testing establishes

those relationships,
it's the groundwork for building the rest of
your product line or company.

And if you don't
make good choices, if you're not thinking
strategically, you will end up
starting all over again.

So the early product
testing, the obvious you must get feedback
on the product.

Everyone knows that. But you also must select
strategic customers, and establish them as
diehard loyal customers,

so that you can build
on top of that start. And with that, I will
turn it over to Laura.

LAURA MARINO: Perfect. So we're going to talk
about the five transitions that startups must
embrace to scale.

But let's start by asking,
why are transitions needed in the first place?

And when you think of
companies, companies typically go through three stages.

An early stage like this
early startup stage, scale up

or high growth stage that I
like to call the teenage stage. And we'll talk about why,
and then in adult stage.

So during the early
stage, the company is still searching for
product market fit, trying

different things to see
what actually resonates with the market, is looking for
a repeatable business model,

and it's doing the team is a
team that essentially is doing whatever it takes to get
the product to market,

to secure those very valuable
early adopters that are going to help be a reference.

In the adult stage
are grown up startups.

They might have gone
through a liquidity event. They might have gone through
IPO, or be part of an M&A.

And these are companies that
are growing now through a more repeatable process. They are more
permanent organizations

that are executing against
a proven business model.

And then you have this
in-between stage, this states,

where the company is no longer
looking for product market fit. What they are trying
to do is scale

to grow the number of customers,
or consumers at a rate, and in a way that
will eventually

allow them to be
cash flow positive, and really take over
this market, where they

found that product market fit. And it is a completely different
ballgame than that early stage

that we were talking about. And in reality, about 60% of
companies that successfully

exit this early stage with
a good product with product market fit end up failing
in this teenage stage.

And I call it the teenage
stage, because when you think for a second about
what teenage years are like,

there's a lot of
opportunity, but there's a lot of uncertainty,
there's a lot of awkwardness,

there is a lot of insight. And I think that
it maps very well to what companies in this
stage are going through.

And to understand why the
stage is so difficult, we need to go back
to look at why.

Well, it turns out that the
early stage strategies that

help those startups get
to this product market fit do not scale.

And if we go back and look
at what those strategies are, is we know companies need to
move fast, test, and iterate.

They may even have to pivot
because they are still not sure what is the right
product for the market

that they are targeting. They have a team that
can wear many hats.

Everybody is doing whatever it
takes to get that product out to market, and to make sure that
they can get those first paying

customers. Communication in the
company is very informal, and that allows for
a lot of agility.

But because it's a small
team, people are all aligned. They know what they
are going after.

And you will have
those people who are the experts, whether
it's the founder, or the first engineer.

They are the ones
who know everything about the product, and
about the business. But because the team is
small, this tribal knowledge

is easily distributed. However, as you start
the high growth,

and you're bringing thousands
of new customers and hundreds of new employees, this approach
becomes totally chaotic,

and it doesn't scale. So what are the changes,
what are those transitions

that those startups
need to embrace when they get to the scale up stage?

And there are five
key transitions. And I'm going to focus primarily
on the third one that's

moving from early product
to scalable product. Because here's where we're
going to be talking about what

are the biggest challenges
from the product perspective during high-growth.

And I'm going to talk
about the last two ones moving from ownership
to partnership in moving

from being opportunistic to
being strategic because this is where we're going to
talk a bit about what are the strategies, the
product strategies for scaling

and expanding. However, because product
touches everything in a company,

I'm also going to talk about
the first two transitions. Because we as
product people, need

to be involved in all of them. So the first transition is
moving from people to process.

And if you're part of
a startup, you probably know that process is
essentially a bad word.

You say process in a startup. And you're like,
oh, no, we're going to become all bureaucratic. But again, the reality is
that in the early stage,

you're going to have those
people who are the players, who are the ones who know
everything about the business,

and about the product itself,
and about the customers. You may have the
situation, where

everything needs to go through
a couple of those people. Well, when the company
starts scaling, those people,

and that tribal
knowledge that they have becomes an obstacle to growth. So what do you need to do?

The first thing you need to
do is embed that expertise, that knowledge of those unique
people into the processes

and the structure
of the company. And that means starting to
do better documentation, and that's across the
board from the HR processes

to documenting the code. So that is you bring
on new engineers. They know what they're touching.

You need to start
creating more training programs, and new onboarding.

You are going to be
hiring a lot of employees. You need to have a process
to get them up to speed fast,

and to get them a consistent
story of what the company is, what the product is.

And you will start seeing
role specialization, roles that did not exist in a startup
that become more important when

you start scaling up. And that could be
sales operations. It could be legal. But the company
needs to start really

looking at what are the things
that this people wearing 10 hats were doing that now need
to get their specialized team.

You also need to create more
formal communication cadence. Again, remember
the communication

can be very informal when
you're a small company. But to keep people aligned
as the company grows,

you need to proactively
communicate. And that's communicating about
the business goals, about

the progress, but also,
from the product perspective is communicating about roadmap.

It's very typical that in
a startup, that there's no formal roadmap, there's no
formal communication of what

the product team is doing. Because everybody knows. They are all
involved like what's the next thing
we're going to try.

But once you've got the
product market fitting, you're evolving this product,
and you're growing a team.

You need to let them
know what's coming. You need to let your sales
team know what is coming. You need to help your
marketing team know what they

need to be ready to present. Because if you don't,
sales will come up with your own version
of what's coming.

And that can be
very, very dangerous. And something else
that's culture,

and it's not something
that's obvious to people, but the culture of a startup
is given by the founders.

And the founders when
they start the company, they have a vision of
what are the values that they want to have
as part of that company.

And that already
distributes organically very easily when the
company is small.

When the company
grows, there has to be an effort to make sure
that culture, those values

really get distributed
to all the new employees. And that's done by doing it
the way in which the company

recruits, how performance
is evaluated and rewarded, and how each employee
treats the other employees.

So the second transition
is moving from relationship to brand. Again, you heard Donna
talk about the players.

In the early stage, especially
if you are in a B2B company, there's going to be
a couple of people who are the ones who
need to be in front

of every potential new
customer because they are the only ones who can
explain truly the value

that the company is bringing. You will have the engineer
who knows everything there is to know about the product.

And he may need
to be pulled into. So when you are
scaling, this sales

that has been based on
relationships from the player, from the CEO really need
to transition to a brand.

You want a brand
that's recognized in the market, that
communicates to the market what

the company is bringing. And so for that,
this is the time, it is really important to
start maturing your marketing

and sales organization. It's important that you
start bringing people who understand demand generation.

If you're in B2C,
bringing people who understand social media
marketing, so that now the brand of the company is
understood in the market.

And it is a really
important period for bringing sales,
especially in B2B

starting to define what's
going to be the sales strategy and enabling sales. Sales enablement and
product marketing

become absolutely critical
because, again, you're not going to have all of those
players in every single sale.

So every sales
person needs to have the tools and the
understanding to be able to explain the value to
position the product correctly.

And again, product
is quite involved in helping with the
sales enablement and with product marketing.

But now, we really
get to the core of where the product people
need to be watching out

for transitions. And this is moving from early
product to scalable product.

And this is where we
really need to watch out for biggest challenges. Now, notice that I'm
not talking about moving

from MVP to scalable product. Because when a company gets to
the scale up high-growth stage,

they are way past MVP. They already have a
product that has proven, that has value in the market,
and has referenced customers.

And now, it's really
about scaling it to a much, much larger
number of customers.

So again, to
understand why there are going to be
challenges in this stage,

let's go back and revisit
how product is developed and evolve in the early stage.

Again, in the early stage, the
product team in engineering,

they need to move
fast and iterate. And engineering is not
worried about building

anything scalable. In fact, engineering
is almost encouraged to do shortcuts, and hooks,
so that they can get something

to market as fast as possible,
so that it can be validated, and it can be iterated on.

The focus is on producing
features, capabilities that are visible to those customers.

You want to show value, so
that those customers actually start saying, yes, I'm
willing to pay for this.

So there's no time
and no attention to building tools
in the back that we

enable an implementation team,
or a technical support team to support those clients.

And then you are really trying
to secure those early adopters, those key customers who will
help you evolve the product,

and who will be
those references. And because it's so important
to ensure that you secure them,

you will be willing to
accommodate some unique things that they may want
to have as long

as they really are
helping you build the product for the market. So if your product
were a building,

by the end of that early
stage, your product might look something like this.

It would have a bunch
of pretty customers specific functionality that
you built to accommodate

those key initial customers. And even if you had
built it in a way that could be used by
others, you know

that was stuff that was
unique for those very important customers.

You will have pieces
of this building that are built very poorly.

These are the
hacks and shortcuts that engineering was doing
in order to get something

out to market very fast. Now, the foundation
will probably

be very weak, and
not ready to take on a lot of new volume,
a lot of new customers.

Again, you were focusing
on building the stuff that could be seen, you are not
focusing your engineering team

on scalability. Now, you will also have, and
this is especially true in B2B,

this is what we typically
call technical debt. But there's another
piece of technical debt that you may have.

And again, in B2B, there will
be a piece of your product that is never finished,
that seems to always need

engineering work ongoing. And this is the
part of the product that engineering needs to
touch every time you secure

a new client because
they have not built the tools or the
APIs that will enable

a professional services
organization to take over, and implement, and configure the
product for every new client.

I also call that part
of technical debt. So why is it that this problem
has existed in the early stage?

But why is it that they become
a really big concern when you're scaling up? So let's first look at what
is the cost of this customer

specific functionality. Again, securing those
early important customers

is absolutely critical. And it's OK for you as a product
manager in that early stage

to accommodate some
of those unique things as long as you can get
those customers on board.

But the problem is
now those customers are accustomed that they
tell you what they want.

And you will go and build it. And as you start scaling,
that is a problem. Because those customers can
start taking over your route.

And you really need to
be evolving your product to serve the market. So you're going to
have to start learning

to say no to those customers. And it's not easy
because, again, they've been accustomed to
getting what they want.

So here are a couple
of strategies, and tips on how to say no. The first thing is to
proactively communicate

to those customers what
you're doing and why. If those customers believe
that your roadmap is

a blank sheet of paper for
them to start filling in, they will be getting
all the list of things

that they want you. But if you proactively
go to them and say, this are the things
we're working towards, and this is why, at a minimum,
they realize that, hey, you

are working on stuff. You're not just waiting for
them to tell you what to do. The other thing you can do,
and this was very successful.

I worked for Intapp. And it was a company
that was focusing on the largest legal companies
in the US, UK, Australia,

and Canada. And you can imagine that every
single one of those large law firms felt that they were
the most important customer

that we could ever have. And they all had their
own list of things that they wanted us to do.

So we started bringing them
together in customer council. We would group
together law firms

that consider themselves peers. We would ask them to share with
us what their challenges were,

and we would share with them
the direction we were going. And it was very interesting to
see one of those customers that

had been pounding their
fists saying you absolutely need to build this. Realize that their peers didn't
care at all about that part

of functionality. So that was really
helpful for them all to realize that we're
actually building a product not

for each of them individually. But when everything
else fails, you

need to be prepared to say no. And what that means
is you need to go to your executives,
and your CEO,

and tell them why it is that
you don't want to accommodate this request from this big
customers, what are the trade

offs that the company would
have to have to accommodate, what would be all those things
that would not get done.

And the reason you need to align
your executives and your CEO with that is because
that customer is

going to escalate to the CEO. They will have a
direct line to the CEO. So you want the CEO to be
aligned and prepared to say no.

I had in one of my
companies actually even more extreme case. We had a big, big
local customer.

And sales was excited
that we had this big local because now they could go and
sell to these other big whales.

But when I came in,
it was clear that we were spending a lot of
engineering and product

resources. Addressing things
that were absolutely unique to that customer.

So I finally spent time with
engineering and product. We laid out in
detail how much time

we were spending on
building stuff that was not reusable for anybody else. And I was able to go
to the executive team,

and I presented at 20%. Of all of our
engineering and product, we're going to build stuff
that was not reusable.

And that if we were to land
another whale like that, we were just going to become
a custom development shop.

And with that, we had to make
the right decision to part ways

with that customer. And it was the
right thing to do. It was painful, but it
was the right thing to do.

So the next big challenge
is technical debt.

And why is it that we have
technical debt and no tools?

Well, every startup at the
end of that early stage

should have some technical debt. Because if you had started
building everything to be fully
scalable, and you had

started building everything,
so that the tools were there for professional
services and support,

you would have run
out of money way before getting your
first product out. And you would have fallen
in one of the mistakes

that Donna was describing
of building too much. So it's natural. It's OK to have
technical debt when

you start the scale up stage. But if you don't start now
paying attention to it,

it really can hurt you. In its most benevolent
way, technical debt

will start slowing you down. Engineering will have a hard
time building functionality on top of pieces of the
code that are fragile,

that are poorly built. And so everything will
become slower to build. But in a more pernicious
way, technical debt

becomes visible
to your customers. And that can actually
take you down. There was a company
way before Facebook,

even before Myspace
called Friendster. And they built a social
network, and they

were being very successful. And all of a sudden,
they got all this success everybody wanted to sign up
for their service, everybody

wanted to be on their service. And their product
could not scale. And it completely
started failing.

And consumers were
not forgiving. They would not come
back to see maybe to see better completely lost.

So it is very important
for you to start addressing technical debt. So how do you go about it?

The first thing you
need to do is realize. It's I call it facing reality. It's revisiting your
engineering allocation.

In the early stage,
when you're first starting your first
product, you probably

can spend 90% of your
engineering bandwidth on building new functionalities. Because only a small piece
will go to fixing things

that are breaking,
or helping with those early implementations,
or maintaining

what functionality that you've
put out because you're just starting with things.

But as you your product
grows in complexity is the number of
clients grow, you

need to start realizing that
a lot of your engineering bandwidth now has to
go to other things.

Maintaining this stuff
that was built already. Because guess what? There's no single feature that's
fully built-in version one.

So if you put some
new functionality, you'd better be sure
that you're going to have to maintain and improve it.

You need to start addressing
that technical debt. You need to start building
those implementation tools that

will allow engineering to
not have to be involved in every implementation,
and you need to have more
bandwidth for things

that break because there's
going to be more clients, and more things could break.

And if you don't
proactively plan for that, the reality is
going to force you

in that direction
in an ugly way. When I joined one
of the companies that I worked for
Topia, and they

had a very complex
platform for helping large companies relocate
employees, when I joined,

I knew that the previous VP
of product had been fired. And when I started talking to
the executives, what they said

was a product and engineer
kept promising things, and they never delivered. So I started looking
at what was going on.

What was going on is that
product and engineering were thinking that
their capacity was still

in the left side. 90% of their time,
they were just going to be building
all this new stuff,

and they were promising
all this new stuff. But the reality is that by
then, the company already

had some big customers,
and engineering kept being pulled into
things that were breaking,

into helping new
implementations because they had to go and set up
things in the database,

and in maintaining stuff
that they had delivered. And that customers
were saying, yes.

But I want it to work different. And they had not realized it. So they kept promising stuff
they couldn't have time

to deliver. So I actually had to go back
and reset the expectations. And so how do you
go about doing that?

The first thing
you need to do is you need to partner
with engineering to figure out what are the
pieces that are going to break.

And then you have to prioritize
paying for technical, re-architecting those pieces
that are most likely to break,

and you put them as
part of the roadmap because it's the same
engineering team. And then you
communicate proactively

to sales and to the executives. Why is it so important that you
slow down on new functionality

and instead take some time
to improve fix rebuild pieces
that the product needs to stay?  So this is really important.

This is something that
every person who's going through this
stage anything product needs to be thinking about.

Now, the next one is moving
from ownership to partnership. And in the early
stage, companies really

want to control everything. They want to control the
interaction with the consumers. But if you scale, there's
an opportunity for you

to be smarter as to where
you use your resources. Partnerships can come
in different flavors.

You can have partners that
help with market access that they resell your product,
or refer your product.

You can have partners
who do the services. So your product
needs implementation. It's great to have partners who
do the professional services.

But you need to have provided
the tools and the APIs for that. And then there's the technology.

And here's where you as the
product leader or product manager needs to
start thinking, where do I put my precious
engineering resources

to improve the areas
that are differentiating? And where could I
just build a partner,

or buy four areas that are
important, but are not key? And a very good example
with use is embedding things

like a BI tool. You don't want your engineering
team to, all of a sudden, be pulled into building a BI
tool when your core product is

a recruiting platform. But if your customers really
want to slice and dice the data in every way possible,
you can embed a BI tool.

Just one of the examples. And then the final
transition that you need to think when you're
trying to think about how

to grow in scale is moving from
being opportunistic to being strategic.

And this actually
has two components that seem a little
bit contradictory.

Focus and expansion. In the early stage, companies
are trying different things

to see what stick. And they may be
pivoting, and they may try this one thing,
and then another one. But once you get to
product market fit,

once you find a market that
you really want to win, you need to focus on that
product in that market,

and you focus your
execution on that, and you stop on things
that were distractions.

But while you're
doing that, you need to start thinking
about expansion. And that is a thought
process start early on.

Because very few companies
that start with one product,

especially if they have VC
funding will get to the size that they and their VCs expect
with that just one product.

So you need to start
thinking, how is it that you're going to expand? And how is it that you are
going to get to the future

that you want? And there's strategies can vary. You can say, OK, I'm
going to start now filling
in a whole family of products. So I start with one. Now, I have those customers.

I can start serving solving
other problems for them. At Intapp, we did that. We started with two products for
niche products for law firms.

And then we built an
entire suite of products to serve all of
their risk needs. And then we expand it
to adjacent industries

because legal
wasn't large enough. But there are other strategies. You can look at the platform.

You can look at
internationalization being up or down market. But you need to start
thinking about it

as you are going through this
high growth scale up stage. So those were the key things.

I'm sure from the real world. So just to recap

you need to be building the market while you're
building the product, or easier to remember maybe,
it takes two to tango.

And that your early
testing customers are going to determine
who you're going to be,

who your product
line is going to be. Make sure that they're

about picking them,

and that they're going
to be reprehensible. And Laura, you want
